title: Brothers embark on mill buying adventure
content: Brothers James Bibb and W.E. Bibb decided to invest in building a cotton mill.
James was a real estate developer and W.E. Bibb was a lawyer. They corresponded by
mail over several months trying to get other investors involved and talked about financial
matters. James was the person who was mostly in charge of this deal although he always
was asking his brother for advice and of course for more money. The very first letter
James sent to his brother expressed his concern about acquiring enough money to pay for
his share of the mill, and he listed the various ways in which he is going to do it. He
encountered many setbacks; some of the investors no longer had substantial amounts of
money to purchase their share, James owed people money in other business dealings of
his, however; throughout the series of letters, the mill deal was still a valid issue
between James and W.E. Bibb. James questioned how and if they had enough money to
not only purchase but to continue to run the mill. Unfortunately the Bibb brothers,
lacking the money, gave up the mill idea, and James decided to start a brick laying
company.
Despite the fact that the Bibb brothers did not succeed in running a successful
mill, many southerners did. The cotton mill industry was a volatile business in the South,
and prospered even during the depression of the 1890's when all other industries in the
South declined. People like James Bibb put together investors to start up these mills in
hopes that they would make a profit. There were probably several reasons why the Bibb
brothers wanted to buy a cotton mill. The textile industry was much more profitable than
iron or coal because the cotton mills could be built anywhere with a water source for
power. After the widespread use of steam power, the mills no longer depended on water
as a power source. Also the labor needed for iron and mining required skilled workers
and mechanics, which were in short supply in the South, while the textile industry needed
people of little experience.
Workers in the cotton mills were mostly white women and children; in fact the
mill industry was the largest employer of southern white women according to William
Cooper. According to Edward Ayers, black men were only permitted to unload cotton
bales outside the mills and black women were not permitted to work there at all. Entire
families would work in a mill because it was easier for them to stay together and this was
beneficial to the employer because they were less liable to leave and find work
elsewhere. Soon mill villages were established with churches, housing, schooling, and
stores where mill employees could carry out their everyday tasks, and by the 1900s, 92
percent of mill workers lived in these communities. If the Bibb brothers had continued
investing in the mill, they would have most likely have had to provide these incentives as
well.
Southerners used cutting edge technology for their textile mills. By 1890, 47
percent of the mills in the South used steam power, and by 1900, 60 percent of the mills
utilized steam power. Other than fuel sources, mill owners also purchased top of the line
machinery that included the automatic loom and the ring spindle, which by 1890 was
used by 90 percent of the southern mills and only 70 percent in the northern mills. This
was the first time that the South manufactured the cotton that they grew instead of
shipping it to the north or some other manufacturing site. The South had become a major
force in the textile industry not only in the Union but internationally; 60 percent of U.S.
output of textiles was supplied from the South.
